action.action-desc: Mr. Rockefeller (for himself and Mr. Blumenthal) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation

form.official-title: To improve passenger vessel security and safety, and for other purposes.

subsection.text: This Act may be cited as the Cruise Passenger Protection Act .

subsection.header: References to title 46, United States Code
subsection.text: Except as otherwise expressly provided, wherever in this Act an amendment or repeal is expressed in terms of an amendment to, or repeal of, a section or other provision, the reference shall be considered to be made to a section or other provision of title 46, United States Code.

section.text: Chapter 35, as amended by section 2 of this Act, is further amended by inserting before section 3523 the following:

subsection.text: This subchapter applies to a passenger vessel (as defined in section 2101(22)) thatâ€”

paragraph.text: is authorized to carry at least 250 passengers;
has on board sleeping facilities for each passenger;
is on a voyage that embarks or disembarks passengers in the United States; and
is not engaged on a coastwise voyage.

subsection.text: This subchapter does not apply to a vessel of the United States operated by the Federal Government or a vessel owned and operated by a State.

section.text: Chapter 35, as amended by section 3 of this Act, is further amended by inserting after section 3521 the following:

paragraph.text: The term Commandant means the Commandant of the Coast Guard.
The term owner means the owner, charterer, managing operator, master, or other individual in charge of a vessel.
Except as otherwise expressly provided, the term Secretary means the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard is operating.

subsection.text: Chapter 35, as amended by section 2 of this Act, is further amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text:
Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of the
Cruise Passenger Protection Act , the Secretary of Transportation shall develop standards for use by an owner of a passenger vessel to provide a prospective passenger with a summary that highlights key terms in the passage contract upfront and before they are binding. In developing the standards, the Secretary of Transportation may consult with other Federal agencies, persons with expertise on admiralty and maritime law, consumer advocates, industry representatives, and such other persons as the Secretary of Transportation considers necessary.
The standards shall include recommendations regarding the following:

subparagraph.text: The standards shall recommend style, formatting, and placement that ensures that the summary is conspicuous.
The standards shall recommend terminology that ensures that the summary is clear, unambiguous, unmistakable, and, to the greatest extent possible, uniform, concise, and not complex.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Transportation shall periodically review and update, as appropriate, the standards.
Not later than 180 days after the date that the standards are developed, an owner of a passenger vessel shallâ€”

subparagraph.text: provide each prospective passenger with a summary in accordance with those standards;
include a prominently accessible link to the summary on each Internet website that the owner maintains for prospective passengers to purchase or book passage on the passenger vessel; and

include the summary in any promotional literature or advertising, through any medium of communication in the United States offering passage or soliciting passengers for ocean voyages anywhere in the world, that the Secretary of Transportation considers necessary to adequately notify a prospective passenger of the key terms in the passage contract before they are binding.

paragraph.text: The standards developed under this subsection shall preempt any related State standards that require a summary that provides less information to a prospective passenger than that required to be provided under this subsection, as determined by the Secretary of Transportation.
The Secretary of Transportation shallâ€”

subparagraph.text: establish a consumer complaints link for passenger use on the Internet website under section 3526(i); and
notify the public ofâ€”

clause.text: the telephone number under subparagraph (A); and
the Internet website under section 3526(i).

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Transportation shall maintain a statistical compilation of all consumer complaints on the Internet website under section 3526(i) that provides a numerical accounting of each category of consumer complaint. The data shall be updated not less frequently than quarterly, be aggregated by passenger vessel, and identify each passenger vessel by name.
The Secretary of Transportation, in coordination with other relevant Federal agencies, may investigate consumer complaints from passengers, includingâ€”

subparagraph.text: cancellations, delays, and port skipping;
lost, damaged, and delayed baggage;
conditions on board the passenger vessel;
problems in obtaining refunds for unused or lost tickets or fare adjustments;
deceptive or misleading advertising; and
compliance with Federal regulations.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Transportation may refer any complaint received under this subsection to the Attorney General or relevant Federal agency for action, as appropriate.

subparagraph.text: Each owner of a passenger vessel shall include in a conspicuous location on each Internet website that the owner of a passenger vessel maintains for passengers to purchase or book passage on a passenger vesselâ€”

clause.text: the telephone number under paragraph (1); and
any other information necessary for a passenger to submit a consumer complaint for resolution.

subparagraph.text: The owner of a passenger vessel shall include the telephone number and Internet address for consumer complaints under paragraph (1) onâ€”

clause.text: any promotional literature or advertising, through any medium of communication in the United States offering passage or soliciting passengers for ocean voyages on passenger vessels, that the Secretary of Transportation considers necessary to adequately notify a prospective passenger of the telephone number and Internet address; and
any electronic confirmation of the purchase of passage on a passenger vessel.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Transportation may impose on any person that violates this section or a regulation under this section a civil penalty of not more than $25,000 for each day during which the violation continues, except that the maximum penalty for a continuing violation is $50,000.
Any person that willfully violates this section or a regulation under this section shall be fined not more than $250,000 or imprisoned not more than 1 year, or both.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Transportation shall issue such regulations as are necessary to implement this section.
In this section:

paragraph.text: The term key terms includes terms related to undisclosed costs and fees, indemnification, waivers, limitations on liability, notice of claim and actions, time limitations, arbitration, forum, and jurisdiction.
The term passage contract means a binding agreement for passage on a passenger vessel.
The term passenger means a citizen of the United States carried on a passenger vessel.
The term passenger vessel means a passenger vessel (as defined in section 2101) to which this subchapter applies.

subsection.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of the Cruise Passenger Protection Act , the Secretary of Transportation shall determine whether any of the enumerated rights in the international cruise line passenger bill of rights, that was adopted by the members of the Cruise Lines International Association, are enforceable under Federal law. The Secretary shall include in the standards developed under section 3525(a) of title 46 United States Code, a statement informing a prospective passengerâ€”

paragraph.text: that the bill of rights is legally enforceable and that the passenger has a private right of action to enforce the bill of rights; and
of any legal action that a prospective passenger may take to enforce the bill of rights.

subsection.header: Advisory Committee for Passenger Vessel Consumer Protection

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Transportation (referred to in this subsection as the Secretary) shall establish an advisory committee for passenger vessel consumer protection to advise the Secretary in carrying out activities relating to passenger vessel customer service improvements.
The Secretary of Transportation shall appoint the members of the advisory committee, which shall be comprised of 1 representative each ofâ€”

subparagraph.text: owners of passenger vessels;
international industry-related associations;
State or local governments with expertise in consumer protection matters;
nonprofit public interest groups with expertise in consumer protection matters;
nonprofit public interest groups with expertise in victim assistance; and
relevant Federal agencies, as determined by the Secretary of Transportation.

paragraph.text: A vacancy in the advisory committee shall be filled in the manner in which the original appointment was made.

Members of the advisory committee shall serve without pay, but shall receive travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of subsistence, in accordance with subchapter I of chapter 57 of title 5, United States Code.
The Secretary of Transportation shall designate, from among the individuals appointed under paragraph (2), an individual to serve as chair of the advisory committee.
The duties of the advisory committee shall includeâ€”

subparagraph.text: evaluating existing passenger vessel consumer protection programs or services;
recommending additional passenger vessel consumer protection programs or services, as necessary; and
recommending to the Secretary key terms in a passage contract that should be highlighted upfront, such asâ€”

clause.text: the country under which the passenger vessel is registered or flagged;
the maximum amount an owner of a passenger vessel will reimburse a passenger for lost or stolen property while on board the passenger vessel; and
where to file a notice of claim or initiate any legal action against the owner of the passenger vessel.

paragraph.text: Not later than February 1 of each of the first 2 calendar years beginning after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall transmit to Congress a report containingâ€”

subparagraph.text: the recommendations made by the advisory committee during the preceding calendar year; and
an explanation of whether and how the industry has implemented each recommendation and, for each recommendation not implemented, the industry's reason for not implementing the recommendation.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, the term passenger vessel has the meaning given the term in section 3525 of title 46, United States Code.

clause.text: be provided to the Federal Bureau of Investigation; and

subparagraph.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of the Cruise Passenger Protection Act , the Commandant, in consultation with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, shall promulgate interim standards for the retention of records of video surveillance.

Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of the Cruise Passenger Protection Act , the Commandant, in consultation with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, shall promulgate final standards for the retention of records of video surveillance.
In promulgating standards under subparagraphs (B) and (C), the Commandant shallâ€”

clause.text: consider the different types of video surveillance systems and storage requirements in creating standards both for vessels currently in operation and for vessels newly built;
consider privacy, including standards for permissible access to and monitoring and use of the records of video surveillance; and

subsection.header: Authority To provide assistance to victims of crimes on board passenger vessels
subsection.text: Chapter 35, as amended by section 5 of this Act, is further amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Assistance to victims of crimes on board certain passenger vessels

subsection.text: The purpose of this section is to provide to a passenger who is an alleged victim of an incident described under section 3523(g)(3)(A)(i)â€”

paragraph.text: a written summary of rights;
a primary point of contact within the Federal Government; and
a means of obtaining immediate, free, and confidential support services.

The Secretary of Transportation shall designate an interim director of victim support services. The interim director shall be an employee of the Department of Transportation and shall serve in the position until a final designation is made under paragraph (2).

Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of the Cruise Passenger Protection Act , the Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with the Department of Justice and other relevant Federal agencies, shallâ€”

subparagraph.text: designate an employee of the Federal Government to serve as the director of victim support services under this section; and
determine an effective way to publicize the toll-free telephone number under subsection (c) and the availability of support services.

paragraph.text: The director of victim support services shallâ€”

subparagraph.text: develop guidance, consistent with the purpose of this section, for the security guide under section 3523(c)(1), including a process to ensure that an owner of a passenger vessel provides a copy of the security guide to a passenger immediately after the vessel is notified that the passenger is an alleged victim of an incident described under subsection (g)(3)(A)(i);
periodically update that guidance, as necessary; and
be the primary liaison between the passenger described in subsection (a) andâ€”

clause.text: the owner of the passenger vessel;
any relevant Federal agency;
any relevant United States embassy or United States consulate; and
any other person that the director of victim support services considers necessary to carry out the purpose of this section.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Transportation shall establish a toll-free telephone number, available 24 hours each day, that a passenger described in subsection (a) can call to initiate the process under subsection (b)(3)(C).
The director of victim support services shall determine the types of support services that a passenger described in subsection (a) can obtain, such asâ€”

paragraph.text: an explanation of how or assistance to obtain support services under this section;
arranging, if appropriate, for mental health and counseling services;
arranging, if possible, for education regarding and advocacy during applicable criminal justice proceedings; and

communicating with that passenger as to the roles of the organization, government agencies, and the owner of the passenger vessel involved with respect to the incident and the post-incident activities.

subsection.text:
Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of the
Cruise Passenger Protection Act , the Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with the Department of Justice, other relevant Federal agencies, non-profit public interest groups with expertise in victim assistance, and such other persons that the Secretary of Transportation considers necessary, shallâ€”

paragraph.text: determine what rights a passenger described in subsection (a) may have under law, such as the right to contact the Federal Bureau of Investigation to report the crime, the right to contact the director of victim support services, and the right to speak confidentially to Federal law enforcement, the director of victim support services, and any other third-party victim advocate without any representative or employee of the passenger vessel present;
develop a written summary of those rights; and
establish a process for a passenger described in subsection (a) to receive the written summary of rights as soon as practicable after an alleged incident described under section 3523(g)(3)(A)(i).

subsection.text: If a passenger described in subsection (a) is deceased or is a minor, or under such other circumstances that the director of victim support services considers necessary, the director may provide support services under this section to a guardian or relative of that passenger.
As appropriate, the resources of the passenger vessel should be used to the greatest extent possible to carry out the purpose under this section.

Nothing in this section may be construed as limiting the obligations that an owner of a passenger vessel may have in providing assistance to a passenger who is an alleged victim of an incident described under section 3523(g)(3)(A)(i).

subsection.header: Availability of incident data via Internet

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Transportation shall maintain a statistical compilation of all incidents described in section 3523(g)(3)(A) on an Internet website that provides a numerical accounting of the missing persons and alleged crimes duly recorded in each report filed under paragraph (3) of that section. Each such incident shall be included in the statistical compilation irrespective of its investigative status. The data shall be updated not less frequently than quarterly, be aggregated by cruise line, identify each cruise line by name, identify each crime and alleged crime as to whether it was committed or allegedly committed by a passenger (as defined in section 2101) or crew member, identify each crime and alleged crime as to whether it was committed or allegedly committed against a minor, and identify the number of alleged individuals overboard. The Secretary of Transportation shall ensure that the compilation, data, and any other information provided on the Internet website is in a user-friendly format.

Each owner of a passenger vessel shall include a prominently accessible link to the Internet website maintained by the Secretary of Transportation under paragraph (1) on each Internet website that the owner maintains for prospective passengers to purchase or book passage on the passenger vessel.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Transportation shall issue such regulations as are necessary to implement this section.
In this section:

paragraph.text: Except as expressly provided otherwise, the term passenger means a citizen of the United States carried on a passenger vessel without regard to whether the individual purchased passage on the passenger vessel or is employed by the owner of the passenger vessel.
The term passenger vessel means a passenger vessel (as defined in section 2101) to which this subchapter applies.

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Transportation, in coordination with the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard is operating, Attorney General, and heads of other relevant Federal agencies, shall conduct a study to determine the feasibility of having an individual on board each passenger vessel (as defined in section 3526 of title 46, United States Code) to provide victim support services, including the support services under section 3526(d) of title 46, United States Code, and related safety and security services, and shall report the findings to Congress. The study shall include consideration of the cost, the benefit to passengers, jurisdiction, and logistics.
